Plans for the current debating season were made definite
at a meeting held last Friday,
presided over by H. Garland
-Hershey, president of the 'debating council.
Dal M. Ghent and W.
Browne Hammond were appointed to take charge of arranging a schedule consisting
mainly of the colleges represented on last year's roster.
The De, Tocqueville medal
contest has been postponed until after Christmas—the date
selected will be announced
later.

The average university graduate, he believes. expects to advance from office boy to president several years after his discharge
from his alma mater. Every college man bc.:lievehimself capable of
performing this Horatio Algerian feat. He is not content to start at
the bottom of the ladder and work upwards. He wants to get aboard
an express elevator and shoot right up to the top. He has lofty
notions concerning his prowess and ability to till an -executive".
position.
Thus, inflated with a sense of his Own importance, the college
graduate will rush into a business office, wave his diploma in the face
of the employment manager and a* for a position paying fifty d 1
tars. a week to start. Then he exiects to be installed in a privat
office with a mahogany desk, rows of push buttons and a private
secretary.
This magazine writer argues further that the college man is
practical and unbusiness-like in his methods. His mind is crammed
with the theories of the Political Economy department, Every commercial prettiest must be worked out by 'statistical surveys and graphs.
He is unable to apply his theories to the everyday business of the
•
average concern.
Undoubtedly business men are correct in their assumption that •
many college graduates make poor employees. However, it seems to
us a fallacy to brand the entire output of our universities as unfit
for commercial work. Such a wholesale condemnation is neither
logical nor fair.
Many college „men are employed every summer in •various
branches of business activity. They work as stevedores on ocean
liners, pound typewriters in business offices, drive taxi cabs and
automobile trucks--and sell magazines? During these short periods
of employment, these men are able to get a rational view of the outside world. They can equalize. the theory of the class room and the
practicality of life. They get an accurate picture of business conditions and commercial practices.
Backed with such experience, the average graduate dpes not sally
forth from the academic cloisters completely ignorant of business
methods. He realitel "'One clearly that the s'.e of his salary will
depend on the amount of his ability. He knAs that .business pays
'
for tangible results and not for good intentions.
Although i.ve dislike to contradict, we fear that our sales manager friend is entirely wrong.

Plans for the current debating season were made definite
at a meeting held last Friday,
presided over by H. Garland
-Hershey, president of the 'debating council.
Dal M. Ghent and W.
Browne Hammond were appointed to take charge of arranging a schedule consisting
mainly of the colleges represented on last year's roster.
The De, Tocqueville medal
contest has been postponed until after Christmas—the date
selected will be announced
later.

The average university graduate, he believes. expects to advance from office boy to president several years after his discharge
from his alma mater. Every college man bc.:lievehimself capable of
performing this Horatio Algerian feat. He is not content to start at
the bottom of the ladder and work upwards. He wants to get aboard
an express elevator and shoot right up to the top. He has lofty
notions concerning his prowess and ability to till an -executive".
position.
Thus, inflated with a sense of his Own importance, the college
graduate will rush into a business office, wave his diploma in the face
of the employment manager and a* for a position paying fifty d 1
tars. a week to start. Then he exiects to be installed in a privat
office with a mahogany desk, rows of push buttons and a private
secretary.
This magazine writer argues further that the college man is
practical and unbusiness-like in his methods. His mind is crammed
with the theories of the Political Economy department, Every commercial prettiest must be worked out by 'statistical surveys and graphs.
He is unable to apply his theories to the everyday business of the
•
average concern.
Undoubtedly business men are correct in their assumption that •
many college graduates make poor employees. However, it seems to
us a fallacy to brand the entire output of our universities as unfit
for commercial work. Such a wholesale condemnation is neither
logical nor fair.
Many college „men are employed every summer in •various
branches of business activity. They work as stevedores on ocean
liners, pound typewriters in business offices, drive taxi cabs and
automobile trucks--and sell magazines? During these short periods
of employment, these men are able to get a rational view of the outside world. They can equalize. the theory of the class room and the
practicality of life. They get an accurate picture of business conditions and commercial practices.
Backed with such experience, the average graduate dpes not sally
forth from the academic cloisters completely ignorant of business
methods. He realitel "'One clearly that the s'.e of his salary will
depend on the amount of his ability. He knAs that .business pays
'
for tangible results and not for good intentions.
Although i.ve dislike to contradict, we fear that our sales manager friend is entirely wrong.
